com.pb.sawdust.tabledata

Interface DataTable

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<DataRow>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractDataTable, AbstractDataTable.DataTablePartition, CoercedDataTable, ColumnDataTable, FixedSizeDataTable, ListDataTable, OrderedDataTable, PieceWiseDataTable, ReadOnlyWrappedDataTable, RowDataTable, WrappedDataTable

    public interface DataTable
extends java.lang.Iterable<DataRow>
    The DataTable interface provides a basic framework for a structure holding similarly structured rows of data. Though this interface is meant to be fairly generic (to avoid restricting implementation details), a few assumptions have been made.
    • Each column in a table will have a specific DataType associated with it, which, as expected, spedifies the type of data that column is to hold. In addition, each column will have a unique label (name), which will be comprised only of alphanumeric characters and "_" (no whitespace or special characters).
    • Each row in a table will be comprised of the same number of columns, in the same order.
    • The ordering of rows in the table at any given time will be deterministic, though this ordering is allowed to change - a single pre-defined ordering need not be guaranteed.
    • All (ordinal) numbering is 0-based. That is, the first row or column in a table has a ordinal index of 0, the second an index of 1, etc. This is set up so as to be consistent with Java's arrays and container classes. Also, allowing for or enforcing 1-based indexing tends to confuse developers, as they have to switch indexing systems depending on the context. The getColumnLabels() provides an illustration of this problem: the indexes of the column names are 0-based (as this is a Java array), but using a 1-based indexing would force the user to add one to these indices to get the correct column index.
    • Indices may be added to tables, which allow rows to be accessed by one or more column values, as opposed to row order numbers.
    • A table will have one primary key column, which contains unique values and can be used to (uniquely) access data rows as opposed to row order numbers. A key is actually just a type of index containing one column of unique values, which makes it more efficient than a generic index. If a primary key column is not specified, then the default/"natural" (0-based) row order numbers will be used. As a note, other key indices may be used with that table, but they will need to use "index" (as opposed to "key") methods.
    • Every table will have an associated TableSchema, which describes the metadata for this table. The schema contains the following information:
      • The name, type, and ordinality of each table column.
      • The table's primary key column.
      • The relationships (if any) between this table and others (such as index keys).
      This last item only has meaning if the other referenced data tables are accessible; such an accesiblity framework is provided through the DataSet inteface.
    Though assumptions have been greatly influenced by database (SQL) standards, they are in no way meant to force the use of database engines in actual implementations.

    Since the DataTable interface extends Iterable<DataRow>, a data table is considered to be naturally "row-based," as opposed to being "column-based." That is, iterating through a data table means iterating through its rows, as opposed to its columns. Again, no explicit restrictions are placed on implementations, but internal structures/engines which hold data in rows instead of columns will probably make the DataRow iterator more efficient. On the other hand, the get...Column methods will probably be less efficient in a row-based structure than a column-based one.

    If desired, data coersion can be enabled, which means that data passed to or from the table that is of a different type than expected will be coerced (if possible) to the correct type. The rules for data coersion between primitive (or equivalent) types is laid out in the Caster class. To cast to a String, the (boxed) object's toString() method is called; to cast from a String, the parseXXX(String) method is used, where XXX is the data type. By default, data coersion should be turned off.

    Because each DataTable will have strengths and weaknesses (e.g. the above-mentioned difference between column- and row-based data tables), switching among implementations should be expected. As such, each DataTable implemenation should have a constructor which takes a DataTable as an argument and essentially copies the source data table into an instance of the the implmentation; copying includes the actual table data, the table schema, and the table's primary table key.

    In addition, to ease loading table data from external sources, each DataTable implmentation should also have a constructor which takes a TableReader as an argument.

      • addRow

        boolean addRow(java.lang.Object... rowData)
        Add a row of data to this data table. This will add the row to the end of the table, in its current ordering. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Parameters:
        rowData - The data for the row, its order (and count) corresponding to the column order (and count) in the data table.
        Returns:
        true if the row was added successfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if data coersion is enabled and any of the values in rowData cannot be coerced.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is not implemented.

      • addRow

        boolean addRow(DataRow row)
        Add a row of data to this data table. This will add the row to the end of the table, in its current ordering. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Parameters:
        row - The row to add. Consistency checking (column names, types, etc. between row and this data table) may not be performed.
        Returns:
        true if the row was added successfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if data coersion is enabled and any of the values in row cannot be coerced.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is not implemented.

      • addColumn

        boolean addColumn(java.lang.String columnLabel,
                java.lang.Object columnData,
                DataType type)
        Add a column to this data table. This requires specifying the column label, type, as well as data values for all existing rows in the table. This will add the column to the end of the current column list. Successfully adding the column will also update the table schema appropriately. This method should allow both object and primitive arrays, so long as they match the column's data type's corresponding object/primitive class. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Parameters:
        columnLabel - The label for the new column.
        columnData - The new column data for the existing rows in the data table. This must be a java array (this is left as Object to allow for primitive and object arrays), with one entry for each row, matching the current row ordering of the data table.
        type - The data type of the new column.
        Returns:
        true if the column was added successfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if columnData is not an array, or if data coersion is enabled and the values in columnData cannot be coerced.
        TableDataException - if columnData does not match type's corresponding object/primitive class, if a column with columnLabel already exists in this data table, or if the length of the data column does not equal the number of rows in the data table .
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is not implemented.

      • addColumn

        boolean addColumn(DataColumn column)
        Add a column to this data table. This will add the column to the end of the current column list. Successfully adding the column will also update the table schema appropriately. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Parameters:
        column - The column to add.
        Returns:
        true if the column was added successfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if data coersion is enabled and the values in column cannot be coerced.
        TableDataException - if a column with the column's label already exists in this data table.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is not implemented.

      • addDataByColumn

        boolean addDataByColumn(java.lang.Object[] data)
        Add column-based data to this data table. Column-based means the data is organized first into a series of columns, and then into a series of row entries. Each Object in data is to be an array, corresponding to a column in the data set, and whose component type is determined by the respective column data type. This method should allow both object and primitive arrays, so long as they match the column's data type's corresponding object/primitive class. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Parameters:
        data - An array of arrays holding the new data by columns.
        Returns:
        true if the data was added successfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if one or more of the elements in data is not an array, if the length of each array in in data is not the same, or if data coersion is enabled and any of the values in data cannot be coerced.
        TableDataException - if an array in data does not match the corresponding column's data type object/primitive class, or if the length of data does not equal the number of columns in the data.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is not implemented.

      • addDataByRow

        boolean addDataByRow(java.lang.Object[][] data)
        Add row-based data to this data table Row-based means the data is organized first into a series of rows, and then into a series of column entries. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Parameters:
        data - An array of row-based data to add to this data table. Its first dimension is the row, and second dimension the column entries. Each row array must have a length equal to the number of columns in this data table.
        Returns:
        true if the data was added successfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if data coersion is enabled and any of the values in data cannot be coerced.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is not implemented.

      • setRowData

        boolean setRowData(int rowNumber,
                 java.lang.Object... values)
        Set the data in the specified row. A variety of input and data checking is performed, however, no checks are made to ensure the the uniqueness of keys on the table are maintained. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Parameters:
        rowNumber - The row whose data will be set.
        values - The new row values, their order (and count) corresponding to the column order (and count) in the data table.
        Returns:
        true if the row was updated succesfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if data coersion is enabled and any of the values in values cannot be coerced.
        TableDataException - if the row number is less than 0 or greater than (1-getRowCount(), if the number of values does not equal the number of columns in the table, or if the values cannot be coerced into the respective data types of the columns.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is not implemented.

      • setRowDataByKey

        <K> boolean setRowDataByKey(K key,
                          java.lang.Object... values)
        Set the data in the specified row as referenced by the row's primary key value. A variety of input and data checking is performed, however, no checks are made to ensure the the uniqueness of keys on the table are maintained. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Parameters:
        key - The primary key value corresponding to the row whose data will be set.
        values - The new row values, their order (and count) corresponding to the column order (and count) in the data table.
        Returns:
        true if the row was updated succesfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if data coersion is enabled and any of the values in values cannot be coerced.
        TableDataException - if the primary key value does not map to a row in the table, if the number of values does not equal the number of columns in the table, or if the values cannot be coerced into the respective data types of the columns.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is not implemented.

      • setColumnData

        boolean setColumnData(int columnIndex,
                    java.lang.Object columnValues)
        Set the data in the specified column. The input array is typed as an Object to allow for primitive arrays. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Parameters:
        columnIndex - The index of the column which will be updated.
        columnValues - An array of data values to put in the column; they should be in the same order as the current table ordering.
        Returns:
        true if the column was updated succesfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if columnValues is not an array, or if data coersion is enabled and the values in columnValues cannot be coerced.
        TableDataException - if the size of columnValues does not equal the number of rows in this table, or if the array type does not match the data type of the column.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is not implemented.

      • setColumnData

        boolean setColumnData(java.lang.String columnLabel,
                    java.lang.Object columnValues)
        Set the data in the specified column. The input array is typed as an Object to allow for primitive arrays. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Parameters:
        columnLabel - The label of the column which will be updated.
        columnValues - An array of data values to put in the column; they should be in the same order as the current table ordering.
        Returns:
        true if the column was updated succesfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if columnValues is not an array, or if data coersion is enabled and any of the values in columnValues cannot be coerced.
        TableDataException - if the size of columnValues does not equal the number of rows in this table, or if the array type does not match the data type of the column.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is not implemented.

      • setCellValue

        boolean setCellValue(int rowNumber,
                   int columnIndex,
                   java.lang.Object value)
        Set the value of a specified cell. A variety of input and data checking is performed, however, no checks are made to ensure the the uniqueness of keys on the table are maintained. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Parameters:
        rowNumber - The row number of the cell to be set.
        columnIndex - The column number of the cell to be set.
        value - The new value for the cell.
        Returns:
        true if the cell value was set succesfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if data coersion is enabled and value cannot be coerced.
        TableDataException - if the row number is less than 0 or greater than (1-getRowCount(), if the column number is less than 0 or greater than (1-getColumnCount(), or if the value cannot be coerced into the data type of the column.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is not implemented.

      • setCellValue

        boolean setCellValue(int rowNumber,
                   java.lang.String columnLabel,
                   java.lang.Object value)
        Set the value of a specified cell. A variety of input and data checking is performed, however, no checks are made to ensure the the uniqueness of keys on the table are maintained. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.

        columnLabel - The column label of the cell to be set.

        Returns:

        Throws:

      • setCellValueByKey

        <K> boolean setCellValueByKey(K key,
                            int columnIndex,
                            java.lang.Object value)
        Set the value of a specified cell identified by a primary key value. A variety of input and data checking is performed, however, no checks are made to ensure the the uniqueness of keys on the table are maintained. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Parameters:
        key - The primary key value corresponding to the row whose data will be set.
        columnIndex - The column number of the cell to be set.
        value - The new value for the cell.
        Returns:
        true if the cell value was set succesfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if data coersion is enabled and value cannot be coerced.
        TableDataException - if the primary key value does not map to a row in the table, if the column number is less than 0 or greater than (1-getColumnCount(), or if the value cannot be coerced into the data type of the column.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is not implemented.

      • setCellValueByKey

        <K> boolean setCellValueByKey(K key,
                            java.lang.String columnLabel,
                            java.lang.Object value)
        Set the value of a specified cell identified by a primary key value. A variety of input and data checking is performed, however, no checks are made to ensure the the uniqueness of keys on the table are maintained. This method is optional, and need not be implemented.
        Parameters:
        key - The primary key value corresponding to the row whose data will be set.
        columnLabel - The column label of the cell to be set.
        value - The new value for the cell.
        Returns:
        true if the cell value was set succesfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if data coersion is enabled and value cannot be coerced.
        TableDataException - if the primary key value does not map to a row in the table, if the column label does not exist in the table, or if the value cannot be coerced into the data type of the column.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if this method is not implemented.

      • deleteRow

        DataRow deleteRow(int rowNumber)
        Delete a row in this data table. All rows subsequent to the deleted one will have their row number decreased by one.
        Parameters:
        rowNumber - The (0-based) number of the row to delete.
        Returns:
        the deleted data row.
        Throws:
        TableDataException - if rowNumber is less than zero or greater than or equal to the number of rows in this data table.

      • deleteRowByKey

        <K> DataRow deleteRowByKey(K key)
        Delete a row in this data table referenced by its primary key value. All rows subsequent to the deleted one will have their row number decreased by one.
        Parameters:
        key - The primary key value of the row to delete.
        Returns:
        the deleted data row.
        Throws:
        TableDataException - if key does not correspond to any row in the table.

      • deleteColumn

        <T> DataColumn<T> deleteColumn(int columnNumber)
        Delete a column from this data table. All columns subsequent to the deleted one will have their row number decreased by one. This method will also modify the table's schema accordingly.
        Parameters:
        columnNumber - The (0-based) index of the column to delete.
        Returns:
        the deleted column.
        Throws:
        TableDataException - if columnNumber is less than zero or greater than or equal to the number of columns in this data table.

      • deleteColumn

        <T> DataColumn<T> deleteColumn(java.lang.String columnLabel)
        Delete a column from this data table. All columns subsequent to the deleted one will have their row number decreased by one. This method will also modify the table's schema accordingly.
        Parameters:
        columnLabel - The label of the column to delete.
        Returns:
        the deleted column.
        Throws:
        TableDataException - if a column with label columnLabel does not exist in the data table .

      • setPrimaryKey

        <K> boolean setPrimaryKey(TableKey<K> primaryKey)
        Set the primary key for this data table. If successful, this will replace the current primary key specified on the table. Because there is no technical restriction that the specified key has been built on (or refers to) this data table, it is preferable to use the setPrimaryKey(String) method to set the table's primary key. This method is intending for primary key switching convenience and efficiency and, as such, the key index will not be rebuilt when this method is called.
        Parameters:
        primaryKey - The key to set as this table's primary key.
        Returns:
        true if the key was set successfully, false otherwise.

      • setPrimaryKey

        boolean setPrimaryKey(java.lang.String columnLabel)
        Set the primary key for this data table by specifying the key column. If successful, this will replace the current primary key specified on the table. If the specified column is not found in the table, then this mehtod will return false.
        Parameters:
        columnLabel - The column to build the key on.
        Returns:
        true if the key was set successfully, false otherwise.
        Throws:
        TableDataException - if the specified column does not contain unique values.

      • getPrimaryKey

        <K> TableKey<K> getPrimaryKey()
        Get the TableKey object corresponding to this data table's primary key. If no primary key has been explicitly set, then the returned object will correspond to the default (0-based) row order numbers.
        Returns:
        this table's primary key.

      • getCellValue

        java.lang.Object getCellValue(int rowIndex,
                            int columnIndex)
        Get a cell in this data table.
        Parameters:
        rowIndex - The (0-based) index of the row containing the cell.
        columnIndex - The (0-based) index of the column containing the cell.
        Returns:
        the cell value corresponding to rowIndex and columnIndex.
        Throws:
        TableDataException - if rowIndex/columnIndex is less than zero or greater than or equal to the number of rows/columns (respectively) in this table.

      • getCellValue

        java.lang.Object getCellValue(int rowIndex,
                            java.lang.String columnLabel)
        Get a cell in this data table.
        Parameters:
        rowIndex - The (0-based) index of the row the containing the cell.
        columnLabel - The label of the column the containing the cell.
        Returns:
        the cell value corresponding to rowIndex and columnIndex.
        Throws:
        TableDataException - if rowIndex is less than zero or greater than or equal to the number of rows in this table, or if columnLabel does not correspond to any column in this table.

      • getCellValueByKey

        <K> java.lang.Object getCellValueByKey(K key,
                                     int columnIndex)
        Get a cell in this data table referenced by the table's primary key.
        Parameters:
        key - The key value corresponding to the row containing the cell.
        columnIndex - The (0-based) index of the column containing the cell.
        Returns:
        the cell value corresponding to key key and columnIndex.
        Throws:
        TableDataException - if columnIndex is less than zero or greater than or equal to the number of columns in this table, or if key does not correspond to any row in this table.

      • getCellValueByKey

        <K> java.lang.Object getCellValueByKey(K key,
                                     java.lang.String columnLabel)
        Get a cell in this data table referenced by the table's primary key.
        Parameters:
        key - The key value corresponding to the row containing the cell.
        columnLabel - The label of the column the containing the cell.
        Returns:
        the cell value corresponding to key key and columnIndex.
        Throws:
        TableDataException - if columnLabel does not correspond to any column in this table, or if key does not correspond to any row in this table.

      • getRow

        DataRow getRow(int rowIndex)
        Get a row of data, ordinally indexed by the current row ordering
        Parameters:
        rowIndex - The ordinal number (0-based) of the row to return.
        Returns:
        the row corresonding to index row.
        Throws:
        TableDataException - if rowIndex is less than 0 or greater than or equal to the number of rows in this table.

      • getRowByKey

        <K> DataRow getRowByKey(K key)
        Get a row of data corresponding to a given key in the table's primary key index. If no primary key column has been specified, then the primary key used will be the default (0-based) row order numbers (essentially an alias for getRow(int)).
        Parameters:
        key - The primary key value for the row of interest.
        Returns:
        the data row corresponding to key.
        Throws:
        TableDataException - if the key does not exist in the table's primary key column.

      • getIndexedRows

        <K> DataTable getIndexedRows(TableIndex<K> index,
                           K... indexValues)
        Get a data table containing rows of data corresponding to a specified index value. Because this is intended to be a view into data rows, the returned data table should be optimized for iterating through the data rows and accessing data by row; other data table operations will probably perform less than optimally.
        Parameters:
        index - The index to be used in the data row retrieval.
        indexValues - The index values corresponding to the row(s) of interest
        Returns:
        a data table containing the rows corresponding to indexValues on index.

      • getColumn

        <T> DataColumn<T> getColumn(int columnIndex)
        Get the column of data corresponding to a given ordinal index. Though generified, this method offers much less type safety than the get*Column methods which explicitly state the column type, and should only be used when the type of the data is not important.
        Parameters:
        columnIndex - The ordinal index (0-based) of the column to return.
        Returns:
        the column corresponding to index columnIndex.

      • getColumn

        <T> DataColumn<T> getColumn(java.lang.String columnLabel)

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the column corresponding to index columnIndex.

      • setDataCoersion

        void setDataCoersion(boolean coersionOn)
        Sets whether this data table will attempt to coerce data to the correct types when setting or getting.
        Parameters:
        coersionOn - If true, then data will be coerced, otherwise it will not.

      • willCoerceData

        boolean willCoerceData()
        Indicates whether this data table will attempt to coerce data to the correct types when setting or getting.
        Returns:
        true if data will be coerced, false otherwise.

      • getTablePartition

        DataTable getTablePartition(int start,
                          int end)
        Get a view of this table corresponding to a range of rows. The start point of the partition is inclusive, and the end point is exclusive. The returned DataTable should be unmodifiable (it cannot itself be modified, nor can it modify the underlying table). There are no specifications as to whether the returned table is a "snapshot" at the time of the method call, or if it is a dynamic view that will change as the underlying table does. Because of this, this method should generally be reserved for fixed (unchanging) data tables.
        Parameters:
        start - The (0-based) row number to start the partition at.
        end - The (0-based) row number to end the partition at (exclusive).
        Returns:
        a view of this table from row start up to row end.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if start or end are less than zero, greater than the number of rows in the underlying table, or if start >= end.
